title-group.article-title: Stock Splits, Bid-Ask Spreads, and Return Variances: An Empirical Investigation of NASDAQ Stocks

abstract.p: This paper examines the bid-ask spread effect on the increase in return variances following the ex-date of splits for a sample of NASDAQ stocks. Comparing two measures of return variance (one based on closing-transaction-price returns and the other based on average-of-bid-ask-price returns), we find that the split-induced increase in stock return variance persists even after controlling for the movements of stock prices between the bid and ask prices. This result suggests that the increase in postsplit variance is not due entirely to the bid-ask spread effect. Our findings for a sample of NASDAQ stocks are consistent with those of Conroy, Harris, and Benet (1990) for a sample of NYSE stocks, but do not support the conclusion of Dubofsky (1991) that exchange trading location is a significant factor in explaining split-induced increase in volatility.
